I'm just going to put this here:

Not any of those anons, but I do think even 20 posts of a green is fine as long as they're relevant to the thread. Now I'm going to be the dick of the tread and say I think the problem is when most of the thread is dominated by the "real life" stories of some of our regular posters. I understand that /hmofa/ pictures and topics are in finite quantity, but I've noticed a dip in the overall atmosphere of the threads because of how cliquish they're getting recently. When identities and real-world discussions start dominating a thread, that's usually the first sign of a deteriorating General. That's not a good way to get new blood in because they know they're going to be overshadowed by the "cool kids".

I'd almost rather have the sluggish pace of generals like /pofg/ if it means you don't have to worry about your green sliding off the thread before you can get decent feedback because it's buried under insides jokes. I don't want to bring down the mood of the thread, but I feel like it needed to be said now before things get bad.

>The both of you walked over to where you were planning on sitting
>You cast your reel as she leaned against you
>The fish she had caught was strung up on a gill line
>Your bobber sat out in the water every now and then ripples being sent out by fish beneath taking nibbles at the bait
>You looked over when you felt her shiver slightly
>She was doing an excellent job trying to hide the fact she was cold but you had noticed anyway
>she leaned up against you trying to siphon any heat she could from your body
>But you had a better idea
>You set your pole down against the log for a moment
>Reaching up to the zipper on your jacket you opened it up
>You patted your lap and spoke
"Get on up here. Cant have you catching a cold."
>She looked up at you with some surprise but obeyed nonetheless
>Her back pushing into your chest and abs the little white fox was snug against your body
>You zipped up the jacket so that only her head was poking out

That's all for now folks!

More to come!

Jageranon out!

Anonymous Wed 11 Oct 2017 10:36:09 No.11983918 Report
Quoted By: >>11984279
>>11983790
That's why I do things in chapters. I can get a clear idea of the start and finish of where I want it to go to and from and what to happen along the way with little need for me to think about what's next outside of filling a chapter full of good moments.

Now, this goes for anyone here writing as a basic tip, though I wouldn't consider myself anywhere near as good as people think I am. Further tips would be:
>Plan the scaffold of the Journey you want before you start on it.
Make a road map of sorts of events in the story, link them together over time, and try to make them all based around different chapters.
>Plan dialogue similarly
What are they talking about? How can you bridge it all? Start on the edges and work your way in.
>Set up some obstacles at certain points
HMOFA is more of a happy story kind of place, and that's fine, but still give your characters some things to deal with on their journey. You don't have to drag them through broken glass and shatter their minds, but that's a good way to make the part when they cuddle more impactful
>don't be afraid to crossfire
Not that I don't think no green writers are, but why not ref other greens? I made the BHA universe so people could have an easy anchor to attach a story to. If you have the means, maybe even collab characters from one story and writer into yours for a moment with that writer.

>set goals
I have a sort of but not really rule about my chapters. 18,000 characters is where I should land per chapter of chickenman. Not exactly any number under or above, but around that. It feels good to have that goal in mind, and sometimes help me push forward.


And most importantly
>time is unlimited
If I've learned anything from watching greens update on here it's that while people may want to read more of your story, they'll happily wait for it. I usually upload a story portion a week and that's usually good for people. Meanwhile fritewag shows up every fortnite to happy anons. You do you, anon.
